poem:
Sudoku Dawn

Gray lines interlace—  
figures whisper, a quiet dance,  
numbers fill the spaces,  
a morning puzzle,  
unsolved mysteries.

Nine quiet lives—  
in their cells at play,  
adding up to truth  
yet holding secrets,  
within ordered chaos.

On paper—  
patterns emerge, vanish,  
like a life unfolding,  
an unfinished sum  
awaiting next week's light.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Observer killer sudoku Click here to access the print version. Normal Sudoku rules apply, except the numbers in the cells contained within grey lines add up to the figures in the corner. No number can be repeated within each shape formed by grey lines. Buy next week’s Observer Digital Edition to see the completed puzzle.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Observer killer sudoku Click here to access the print version. Normal Sudoku rules apply, except the numbers in the cells contained within grey lines add up to the figures in the corner. No number can be repeated within each shape formed by grey lines. Buy next week’s Observer Digital Edition to see the completed puzzle.
